hostNotes.text: Welcome. I am X and today we will explore equanimity and excpectations  for around 20 minutes. We’ll be doing an audio exercise, followed by time for reflection and finally sharing with each other – if we're up for it.

Let’s start with a mini check-in. How are you feeling right now? Please answer in two-three words. X, would you like to start? > Let everyone in the session, including yourself, check in one by one. Thank you all for checking in. Let’s get started.
Find a comfortable position. I will start the audio exercise and we'll meet back here afterwards. > Tap play to start the audio exercise

Now we’ll take 1 minutes to reflect on our own. How was that experience for you? “What do you notice about your list of “helpful expectations”? Do they seem doable? Do you see any themes or generalities?
What do you notice about your list of “unhelpful expectations”? What do the items on this list have in common, if anything? What impact might these “unhelpful expectations” be having on you?
What do you notice about feelings or sensations that arise in you as you think carefully about these expectations you’re holding for yourself today?”

You can take notes on a piece of paper or just mental notes in your head. And there is no right or wrong here, our answers are our own. 1 minute starting now. > Press play to start the timer. That’s 1 minute and it’s time to move on.
Now we are getting into the sharing part. We have three rules for sharing:

1. 1. \*\*What is said in here, stays in here.\*\* 2. \*\*All you need to do is listen.\*\* There is no fixing, helping or advice-giving needed. We are just showing up and exploring what ourselves and others are going through.

   3. \*\*Everything on the inside is okay.\*\* Anger, love, hatred, sadness. Whatever shows up. No wrongs, no rights. It is what it is. There will be a timer set for 2 minutes as an indicator. If you don’t want to share you can always say ‘pass’.
Who would like to start? > Let everyone (or as many as you got time for) share one by one. Press play to start the timer. Re-start for each new sharing. Thank you so much, everyone.

content.text: “What do you notice about your list of “helpful expectations”? Do they seem doable? Do you see any themes or generalities?
What do you notice about your list of “unhelpful expectations”? What do the items on this list have in common, if anything? What impact might these “unhelpful expectations” be having on you?
What do you notice about feelings or sensations that arise in you as you think carefully about these expectations you’re holding for yourself today?”

hostNotes.text: Well done. If you’re up for it, you can continue what we started here today with a mission.
In the next week consider any expectations you create. Are they helpful or unhelpful? How could you reframe the expectation from unhelpful to helpful?

As you’ve reflected on what you can bring from this to the rest of your day, take this opportunity to practice making space for things on the inside during the rest of today, and see where that takes you.

content.text:
If you’re up for it, you can continue with this mission.

When we utilize self-compassion, it can shift how we see things. We can reappraise the things that occur in our life, in the lives of others, and it helps us to create a more realistic outlook.
content.heading: Well done

en.name: Expectations

hostNotes.text: > Press play to start the audio exercise

en.description: Self-compassion helps us to accept our shortcomings or failures as a normal part of the human experience and an opportunity for growth. We can also learn to accept that not everything is within their control. Sometimes, even with the best efforts, we may not achieve what they had hoped for. There may be things beyond them that contribute to this reality. When we exercise self-compassion we can set expectations for ourselves out of a desire to be healthy and flourishing rather than from a place of self-criticism.
